trial_identification.studytitle: Australasian Carbohydrate Intolerance Study in Pregnancy
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Australasian Carbohydrate Intolerance Study in Pregnancy
trial_identification.secondaryid: Perinatal Society of Australia and New Zealand (PSANZ) Impact Registry/Perinatal Trials Registry: PT0353

conditions.healthcondition: Women with glucose intolerance in pregnancy

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other reproductive health and childbirth disorders

interventions.interventions: Glucose Intolerance Group: Routine obstetrics care by the attending obstetric team, dietary advice, glucose monitoring and insulin therapy as needed Study continued until recruitment was completed, final follow up was 3 months postpartum.
interventions.comparator: Not Gestational Diabetes group: Routine obstetrics care by the atending obstetric team.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcomes among infants were a composite measure including the serious perinatal complications (defined as one or more of the following: death, shoulder dystocia, bone fracture, and nerve palsy)
Primary outcomes among infants were a composite measure including admission to the neonatal nursery
primaryOutcome.timepoint: During neonatal period up to primary hospital discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcomes among infants were a composite measure including jaundice requiring phototherapy.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: During neonatal period up to primary hospital discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary clinical outcomes among the women were the need for induction of labour.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Maternal health status was assessed 3 months post partum by means of the Medical Outcomes Study (SF-36).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary clinical outcomes among the women were the need for caesarean section.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Maternal health status was assessed 3 months post partum by means of the Medical Outcomes Study (SF-36).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcomes among the infants included components of the composite primary outcome, gestational age at birth, birth weight, and other measure of health.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At birth and up to primary hospital discharge

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcomes among the women included the number of prenatal visits to a health professional, the mode of birth, weight gain during pregnancy measured at initial pregnancy booking visit, at 28 weeks and last antenatal visit, the number of antenatal admissions, and the presence of absence of pregnancy-induced hypertension.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Singleton or twin pregnancy with a positive Glucose Challenge Test (GCT) or risk factors for Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) at 16-30.0 weeks gestation and at 24-34.6 weeks gestation, an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) result: fasting <7.8mmol/L and 2 hour > or equal to 7.8mmol/L and < or equal to 11.0mmol/L.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Previously treated Glucose Intolerance in Pregnancy or Gestational Diabetes, Chronic active systemic disease (excluding essential hypertension), Diabetes, Gestational Diabetes OGTT result (fasting > or equal to 7.8mmol/L and/or 2 hr > or equal to 11.1mmol/L), Glucose Intolerance in Pregnanct detected in current pregnancy before 20 weeks.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Discipline of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, University of Adelaide Women's & Children's Hospital 72 King William Rd North Adelaide SA 5006

fundingsource.fundingaddress: National Health and Medical Research Council GPO Box 1421 Canberra ACT 2601

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Gestational impaired glucose tolerance, associated with subsequent maternal non-insulin dependent diabetes, is routinely screened for during pregnancy, despite the lack of consensus as to the value of such screening and the subsequent management. Epidemiological studies suggest maternal and perinatal morbidity, often attributed to glucose intolerance in pregnancy, is more likely to be due to the effects of maternal age, maternal obesity or the knowledge of the diagnosis and the consequences of subsequent management. The aim of this multicentre study is to assess two forms of antenatal care in women with impaired glucose tolerance; routine antenatal care with 'diabetic style care'. The primary outcomes relate to important perinatal and maternal morbidity. The results will help answer the question as to whether substantial resources should be applied to the diagnosis and management of glucose intolerance in pregnancy. This trial assesses two forms of care for treating women with glucose intolerance of pregnancy.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Effect of treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus on pregnancy outcomes. Crowther CA, Hiller JE, Moss JR, McPhee AJ, Jeffries WS, Robinson JS; Australian Carbohydrate Intolerance Study in Pregnant Women (ACHOIS) Trial Group.. N Engl J Med. 2005 Jun 16;352(24):2477-86
